column1: Gaeta (Italian: [ɡaˈeːta]; Latin: Cāiēta; Ancient Greek: Καιήτη
column2: romanized: Kaiḗtē) is a city and comune in the province of Latina
column3: in Lazio
column4: central Italy. Set on a promontory stretching towards the Gulf of Gaeta
column5: it is 120 kilometres (75 miles) from Rome and 80 km (50 mi) from Naples.

column1: The town has played a conspicuous part in military history; its fortifications date back to Roman times
column2: and it has several traces of the period
column3: including the  1st-century mausoleum of the Roman general Lucius Munatius Plancus at the top of the Monte Orlando.

column1: Gaeta's fortifications were extended and strengthened in the 15th century
column2: especially throughout the history of the Kingdom of Naples (later the Two Sicilies). Present day Gaeta is a fishing and oil seaport
column3: and a renowned tourist resort. NATO maintains a naval base of operations at Gaeta.

column2: situated on the slopes of the Torre di Orlando
column3: a promontory overlooking the Mediterranean Sea. Inhabited by the Oscan-speaking Italic tribe of the Aurunci at least by the 10th-9th century BC
column4: the town was an ancient Ionian colony of the Samians according to Strabo
column5: as he believed its name stemmed from the Ancient Greek καιέτας
column6: which means "cave"
column7: probably referring to the several harbours.

column2: Gaeta was instead named after Caieta
column3: Aeneas’ (another legend says Ascanius') wet-nurse
column4: whom he buried here.

column2: famous for its lovely and temperate climate
column3: like the neighbouring Formia and Sperlonga
column4: was a tourist resort and site of the seaside villas of many important and rich characters of Rome. Like the other Roman resorts
column5: Caieta was linked to the capital of the Empire by Via Appia and its end trunk Via Flacca (or Valeria)
column6: through an opposite diverticulum or by-road. Its port was of great importance in trade and in war
column7: and was restored under Emperor Antoninus Pius. Among its antiquities is the mausoleum of Lucius Munatius Plancus.

column1: At the beginning of the Middle Ages
column2: after the Lombard invasion
column3: Gaeta remained under suzerainty of the Byzantine Empire. In the following years
column4: like Amalfi
column5: Sorrento and Naples
column6: it would seem to have established itself as a practically independent port and to have carried on a thriving trade with the Levant.

column1: As Byzantine influence declined in Southern Italy the town began to grow. For fear of the Saracens
column2: in 840 the inhabitants of the neighbouring Formiæ fled to Gaeta. Though under the suzerainty of Byzantium
column3: Gaeta had then
column4: like nearby ports Naples and Amalfi
column5: a republican form of government with a dux ("duke"
column6: or commanding lord under the command of the Byzantine Exarch of Ravenna)
column7: as a strong bulwark against Saracen invasion.

column2: it became a lordship ruled by hereditary hypati
column3: or consuls: the first of these was Constantine (839–866)
column4: who in 847 aided Pope Leo IV in the naval fight at Ostia. At this same time (846) the episcopal see of Gaeta was founded when Constantine
column5: Bishop of Formiae
column6: fled thither and established his residence. He was associated with his son Marinus I. They were probably violently overthrown (they disappear suddenly from history) in 866 or 867 by Docibilis I
column9: entered into treaties with the Saracens and abandoned friendly relations with the papacy. Nevertheless
column10: he greatly expanded the duchy and began construction of the palace. Greatest of the hypati was possibly John I
column11: who helped crush the Saracens at Garigliano in 915 and gained the title of patricius from the Byzantine Emperor Constantine VII.

column1: The principle of co-regency governed the early dynasties:  Docibilis associated John with him and John in turn associated his son Docibilis II with him. In 933
column2: three generations were briefly co-ruling: John I
column3: Docibilis II
column4: and John II. On the death of Docibilis II (954)
column5: who first took the title dux
column6: the duchy passed from its golden age and entered a decline marked by a division of territory. John II ruled Gaeta and his brother
column8: ruled Fondi with the equivalent title of duke. Outlying lands and castles were given away to younger sons and thus the family of the Docibili slowly declined after mid-century.

column2: but improbably
column3: from the end of the 9th century
column4: the principality of Capua claimed Gaeta as a courtesy title for the younger son of its ruling prince. In the mid-10th century
column5: the De Ceremoniis of Constantine VII Porphyrogenitus lists the ceremonial title "prince of Gaeta"  among the protocols for letters written to foreigners.Prince Pandulf IV of Capua captured Gaeta in 1032 and deposed Duke John V
column6: assuming the ducal and consular titles. In 1038
column7: Prince Guaimar IV of Salerno took it from him and
column9: established the Norman counts of Aversa
column10: who were afterwards princes of Capua
column11: as puppet dukes. The native dynasty made a last attempt to wrest the duchy from Guaimar in 1042 under Leo the Usurper.

column2: the Gaetans elected their own Lombard duke
column3: Atenulf I. His son
column4: Atenulf II
column5: was made to submit to the Norman Prince Richard I of Capua in 1062
column6: when Gaeta was captured by Jordan Drengot. In 1064
column7: the city was placed under a line of puppet dukes
column9: who had usurped the ducal and consular titles. These dukes
column11: ruled Gaeta with some level of independence until the death of Richard of Caleno in 1140. In that year
column12: Gaeta was definitively annexed to the Kingdom of Sicily by Roger II
column13: who bestowed on his son Roger of Apulia
column14: who was duly elected by the nobles of the city. The town did maintain its own coinage until as late as 1229
column15: after the Normans had been superseded by the centralising Hohenstaufen.

column1: In the many wars for possession of the Kingdom of the Two Sicilies
column2: Gaeta
column3: owing to its important strategic position
column4: was often attacked and defended bravely. In 1194 the Pisans
column5: allies of Emperor Henry VI in the conquest of the kingdom
column6: took possession of the city and held it as their own.

column1: In 1227 the Hohenstaufen Emperor Frederick II was in the city and strengthened the castle. However
column2: in the struggle between Emperor Frederick and the Papacy
column3: in 1228 it rebelled against Frederick II and surrendered to the pope
column4: after the Papal forces destroyed the imperial castle in the fray. After the peace of San Germano of 1230
column5: it was given back to the Sicilian kingdom. In 1233
column6: Frederick regained control of the important port and fortress. In 1279 Charles I of Anjou rebuilt the castle and enhanced the fortifications. In 1289 King James II of Aragon besieged the city in vain. From 1378 Gaeta hosted for some years antipope Clement VII. The future King of Naples Ladislaus lived in Gaeta from 1387. Here
column9: whom he repudiated three years later.

column1: King Alfonso V of Aragon (as Alfonso I of Naples) made Gaeta his beachhead for the conquest of the Kingdom of Naples in 1435
column2: besieged it
column3: and to his own disadvantage displayed great generosity
column4: by aiding those unable to bear arms who had been driven out from the besieged town. After a disastrous naval battle he captured it
column5: and gained control of the kingdom. He enlarged the castle
column6: which became his royal palace
column7: and created a mint. In 1451 the city was home to the Treaty of Gaeta
column8: stipulated between Alfonso V and the Albanian lord
column9: Skanderbeg: the treaty ensured protection of the Albanian lands in exchange for political suzerainty of Skanderbeg to Alfonso.

column2: king Charles VIII of France conquered the city and sacked it. The following year
column3: however
column4: Frederick I of Aragon regained it with a tremendous siege which lasted from 8 September to 18 November.

column1: In 1501 Gaeta was retaken by the French; however
column2: after their defeat at the Garigliano (3 January 1504)
column3: they abandoned it to Gonzalo Fernández de Córdoba
column4: Ferdinand the Catholic's general.

column2: admiral of Charles V
column3: defeated a French fleet in the waters off Gaeta and gave the city to its emperor. Gaeta was thenceforth protected with a new and more extensive wall
column4: which also encompassed Monte Orlando.

column1: In the War of the Spanish Succession
column2: on 30 September 1707 Gaeta was stormed and taken after a three-month siege by the Austrians under General Daun. On 6 August 1734 it was taken by French
column3: Spanish and Sardinian troops under the future King Charles of Naples after a stubborn defense by the Austrian viceroy of four months. Charles' own daughter Infanta Maria Josefa of Spain was born here in 1744. The fortifications were again strengthened; and in 1799 it was temporarily occupied by the French.

column1: On 18 July 1806 it was captured by the French under André Masséna
column2: after an heroic defence. It was created a duché grand-fief in the Napoleonic Kingdom of Naples
column3: but under the French name Gaete
column4: for finance minister Martin-Michel-Charles Gaudin
column5: in 1809 (family extinguished in 1841).

column1: On 8 August 1815 it capitulated to the Austrians after a three months' siege.  It had been attacked and partially reduced by ships of the Royal Navy on 24 July 1815.
After his flight from the Roman Republic
column2: Pope Pius IX took refuge at Gaeta in November 1848.  He remained in Gaeta until 4 September 1849.
the USS Constitution while in port at Gaeta
column3: received onboard King Ferdinand II and Pope Pius IX
column4: giving them a 21-gun salute. This was the first time that a Pope set foot on American territory or its equivalent.

column3: it was the scene of the last stand of Francis II of the Two Sicilies against the forces of United Italy.  The king offered a stubborn defense
column4: shut up in the fortress with 12
column5: 000 men and inspired by the heroic example of Queen Maria Sophie after Garibaldi's occupation of Naples.  It was not until 13 February 1861 that Francis II was forced to capitulate when the withdrawal of the French fleet made bombardment from the sea possible
column6: thus sealing the annexation of the Kingdom of Naples to the Kingdom of Italy. Cialdini
column8: received the victory title of Duke of Gaeta. During the functioning of the Government of Montenegro in exile from 1919 to 1924
column9: that supported the Petrović-Njegoš dynasty and opposed the rule of the house of Karađorđević in Yugoslavia (The Greens) were located in Gaeta.

column1: After the Risorgimento and until World War II
column2: Gaeta grew in importance and wealth as a seaport. The nearby town of Elena
column3: separated after the Risorgimento and named after the queen of Italy
column4: was reunited to Gaeta following World War I. Mussolini transferred Gaeta from the southern region known today as Campania (formerly Terra di Lavoro
column5: to which it is historically and culturally attached) to the central region of Lazio.

column1: After the king dismissed Mussolini in the summer of 1943
column2: the latter was initially taken via Gaeta to the island prison of Ponza.  After Italy surrendered to the Allies
column3: however
column4: the town's fortunes began to decline. Recognizing its strategic importance
column5: and fearful of an Allied landing in the area
column6: German troops occupied the city and expelled most of the population. The zone of exclusion began with a five-kilometre border from the historical city centre. Soon after
column8: the population was expelled even beyond this point. The Gaetani were finally ordered to leave the area completely. Those who could not were placed in a concentration camp
column9: and a few were taken to Germany.

column1: Following the Allied advance across the Garigliano and the Allied occupation of Rome
column2: the Gaetani were allowed to return to their city and begin the process of rebuilding. In subsequent decades the city has boomed as a beach resort
column3: and it has seen some success at marketing its agricultural products
column4: primarily its tomatoes and olives. Many of its families count seamen among their number. However
column5: the decades since World War II have been as difficult for Gaeta as they have been for most of Italy's Mezzogiorno. In particular
column6: its importance as a passenger seaport has nearly vanished: ferries to Ponza and elsewhere now leave from the nearby town of Formia. All attempts to build a permanent industry as a source of employment and economic well-being for the town have failed. Notable losses include the Littorina rail line (now used as a parking lot and a marketplace)
column7: the AGIP refinery (nowadays a simple depot)
column9: which has become an unused industrial relic.

column1: Gaeta does have a viable tourism industry
column2: as it is a popular seaside resort. Its warm
column3: rain-free summers attract people to its numerous beaches along the coastline
column4: such as Serapo and Sant'Agostino Beaches. Nearly equidistant to both Naples and Rome
column5: Gaeta is a popular summer tourist destination for people from both cities' metropolitan areas.

column1: The main attractions of the city include:
The massive Aragonese-Angevine Castle. Its origins are uncertain: most likely it was built in the 6th century
column2: in the course of the Gothic War
column3: or during the 7th century to defend the town from the Lombards' advance. First documents mentioning it date to the age of Frederick II of Hohenstaufen
column4: who strengthened it in 1233. The current structure is made of two different edifice: the "Angevine" one
column5: in the lower sector
column6: dating to the House of Anjou's rule in the Kingdom of Naples; and the "Aragonese"
column9: together with the other fortifications that made Gaeta one of the strongest fortresses in southern Italy. The Angevine wing housed a military jail until the 1980s (German war criminal officers Walter Reder and Herbert Kappler were imprisoned here). Now it is a property of the Gaeta municipality
column10: which uses it for conferences and exhibitions. In the dome of the tallest tower is the Royal Chapel
column11: built by King Ferdinand II of the Two Sicilies in 1849.

column1: The Mausoleum of Lucius Munatius Plancus (22 BCE) is a cylindrical travertine monument at the top of Monte Orlando (168 m). It stands at 13.20 m and has a diameter of 29.50 m. Another important Roman public man
column2: Lucius Sempronius Atratinus
column3: Mark Antony's fleet commander
column4: has a mausoleum
column5: sited in the more recent district of Gaeta: of similar diameter
column6: it is however not as well preserved.

column2: mentioned as early as the 11th century and visited
column3: among the others
column4: by St. Francis and Saint Philip Neri. The Crucifix Chapel was built in 1434 over a rock which had fallen from the nearby cliffs. From the sanctuary the Grotta del Turco can be visited: it is a grotto which ends directly in the sea and where the waves create atmospheric effects of light.

column1: Sanctuary of Santissima Annunziata - A church and adjacent hospital were built at the site in the 14th century
column2: but rebuilt at the beginning of the 17th century in Baroque style by Andrea Lazzari. It houses works by Renaissance painters including A Sabatini and GF Criscuolo; as well as late-Baroque artists such as Giordano
column3: Conca and Brandi. The church has a Gothic-style sarcophagus of Enrico Caracciolo. Also notable is the Golden Chapel or Grotto
column4: a Renaissance-style chapel where Pope Pius IX meditated before issuing the dogma of the Immaculate Conception. The ceiling is gilded
column5: and the walls contain 19 canvases (1531) by Criscuolo. The main altarpiece is an Immacolata by Pulzone.

column1: San Giovanni a Mare - The church was initially built outside the old sea walls
column2: by the hypate Giovanni IV in the 10th century. It combines the basilica form with the Byzantine one. The simple façade has a Gothic portal and a dome
column3: while the interior has a nave with two aisles. The inner pavement is slightly inclined to allow waters to flow away in the case of maritime floods.

column1: The Cathedral of Assunta e Sant'Erasmo was erected over a more ancient church
column2: Santa Maria del Parco
column3: and consecrated by Pope Paschal II in 1106: it had a nave with six aisles separated by columns with Gothic capitals. In 1778
column4: however
column5: two of the aisles were suppressed and the Gothic lines hidden. In the 13th century Moorish arches were added over the capitals. In 1663 the crypt was decorated in Baroque style. The interior houses a banner from the Battle of Lepanto
column6: donated by Pope Pius V to Don John of Austria
column7: who used it as his admiral's flag. The main sight of the church is however the marble Paschal candelabrum
column9: from the late 13th century: it is in Romanesque style
column10: decorated with 48 reliefs in 4 vertical rows
column11: telling the Stories of the Life of Jesus. There are also paintings by Giacinto Brandi and Giovanni Filippo Criscuolo. The cathedral contains the relics of St. Erasmus
column12: transferred from Formia; the remarkable campanile
column14: dates from the 12th century. At the base are slabs and  parts of columns from ancient Roman edifices.

column1: The Chapel of the Crucifix is a curiosity: built on a huge mass of rock that hangs like a wedge between two adjoining walls of rock. Legend tells how the rock was thus split at the moment of our Saviour's death.
San Francesco - According to the legend
column2: the church was constructed by the Saint himself in 1222
column3: was in fact built by Frederick II
column4: in very fine Gothic-Italian style
column5: and contains paintings and sculpture by many of the most famous Neapolitan artists.

column1: The parish church of Santa Lucia
column2: the former St. Maria in Pensulis
column3: was once a Royal chapel and here prayed Margherita of Durazzo and king Ladislaus. It had originally Romanesque and Sicilian-Arab lines
column4: but in the 1456 it was rebuilt in Renaissance style
column5: and in 1648 adapted to a Baroque one. The side has a Mediaeval pronaos with ancient fragments and  figures of animals.

column1: The Medieval Quarter of Gaeta is itself of interest. It lies on the steep sides of Mount Orlando and has characteristic houses from the 11th-13th centuries.Gaeta is also the centre of the Regional Park of Riviera di Ulisse
column2: which includes Monte Orlando
column3: Gianola and the Scauri Mounts
column4: and the two promontories of Torre Capovento and that of Tiberius' Villa at Sperlonga.

column2: a NATO base was established in Gaeta with support facilities on Monte Orlando. This was done following the transfer of the responsibilities of Lead Nation for NATO Naval Forces in the Mediterranean from the United Kingdom to the United States. The British Mediterranean Fleet was abolished - its former base in Malta was no longer exclusively under British control due to that nation having achieved independence from the UK.

column1: It is currently used as the home port for the flagship of the United States' Sixth Fleet. The Sixth Fleet commander
column2: typically a 3-Star US Navy Vice-Admiral
column3: has operational control of Naval task forces
column4: battle groups
column5: amphibious forces
column6: support ships
column8: and submarines in the Mediterranean Sea. Gaeta's role has been important since the early 19th century to the US Navy's commitment to forward presence. Pope Pius IX and King Ferdinand II of the Kingdom of Two Sicilies
column9: paid visits to the USS Constitution while in Gaeta in 1849.  Nine ships have been stationed in Gaeta
column10: with the primary mission of serving as the flagship for the Sixth Fleet commander. The first was USS Little Rock (CG-4). Other Sixth Fleet flagships included USS Springfield (CLG-7)
column14: USS Belknap (CG-26) and USS La Salle (AGF-3). The current flagship is USS Mount Whitney (LCC-20).

column1: The town is host to the families of the crews who work on the ship. There was a DOD school for American children and the US Naval Support Activity
column2: Gaeta
column3: which provided health care and other services until it was closed down in 2005. The NATO base itself was located on Monte Orlando
column4: which overlooks the Gulf of Gaeta. It has recently been transferred to a shore based facility where the Commander Sixth Fleet also operates.

column2: while similar to the nearby Neapolitan

column1: Distinctive local cuisine includes the tiella
column2: which resembles both a pizza and a calzone.  The tiella can be made with a number of stuffings.  Typical stuffings include diced calamari with parsley
column3: garlic
column4: oil
column5: hot pepper and just enough tomato sauce for color.  Other stuffings include escarole and baccalà (dried codfish)
column6: egg and zucchini
column9: and ham and cheese. The town is also notable for its distinctive brand of olives
